review.title: SS4MCT: A Statistical Stemmer for Morphologically Complex Texts
review.abstract: There have been multiple attempts to resolve the various formation matching problem in information retrieval. Stemming is a common strategy to this end. Among many approaches for stemming, statistical stemming has shown to be effective in a few number of languages, particularly those highly inflected ones. Common statistical approaches heavily relies on string similarity in terms of prefix and suffix matching. In this paper we propose a method that is able to find any popular affix in any position of a word; specifically finding infixes is a required task in Persian, Arabic, and Malay particularly in irregular formations and is a future challenge in informal texts. The proposed method aims at finding a number of transformation rules for expanding a word with its inflectional/derivation formations. Our experimental results on CLEF 2008 and CLEF 2009 English-Persian CLIR tasks indicate that the proposed method significantly outperforms all the baselines in terms of MAP.

sections.heading: 2 SS4MCT: A Statistical Stemmer for Morphologically Complex Texts
sections.text: In this section, we propose an unattended method for finding inflections in a language. To this end, we first introduce a transformation rule that represents an edit path that transforms the word w into w ′ based on a number of actions. Our goal is to estimate the probability of each transformation rule P (R) and to calculate the probability of generating inflections for a particular term (i.e. p (w ′ | w)). In sections 2.1 and 2.2, we present the proposed method in more detail, and in section 2.3, we propose a rating framework for the method.

sections.heading: 2.1 Transformation Rules
sections.text: Each transformation rule contains a number of actions that turn a word into an inflection. If two terms are k points apart, the rule that transforms the input term into the output term contains k actions and the maximum probability of the POS tag of the input word. Each action consists of the following attributes: c, the differential sign, p, the position of that character (start, middle, and end), and o, the corresponding operation on the character in the MED algorithm (delete or insert). Intuitively, we define a few general positions for attachments to avoid the conciseness of the rules. A replacement operation can be replaced by a few insert / delete operations, so we ignore the replacement operation. Table 1 shows a series of examples of the rules.

sections.heading: 2.2 Probability of the Rules
sections.text: To calculate the probability of generating a diffraction for a particular term (i.e. p (w ′ | w)), we can calculate the transformation rule (R) between w and w ′ and estimate p (w ′ | w) by p (R). To calculate the probability of each rule, we use a large collection of words from a document collection. For each word pair in the collection (w and w ′), we calculate the rule for transforming w into w ′ and count the number of times this rule has occurred in the collection. The higher the occurrence of a rule, the more likely it is that it is valid. Finally, we estimate the rule probability with maximum probability.

sections.heading: 2.3 How to Evaluate the Algorithm
sections.text: In this section, we provide a framework for the originating algorithm to evaluate its effectiveness. We use dictionary-based cross-border information retrieval (CLIR) for this purpose. In heavily inflected languages, bilingual dictionaries contain only original forms of words. Therefore, query systems in dictionary-based CLIR are required to either stammer or leave documents and queries intact [8,4,12] or to extend the query by inflections. We have opted for the query enhancement approach, which is a widely used approach to compensate for the lack of diffraction options [9,3,5]. To this end, we used the following probabilistic framework [5]: p (ci, j | qi) = 1 p (ci, j ²) = 1 p (ci, ci ², i ², j ²) = 1 c (c ², j ²) = 1 c (j ²) = 1 (c ²).

sections.heading: 3.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: We used the Kullback-Leibler statistical language modeling framework of the Lemur toolkit for our on-demand task. Dirichlet Prior was chosen as the translation strategy. We used STeP1 [13] in our stemming process in Persian. Queries are supplemented with the top 50 terms generated by the feedback model [14,6]. We used Google's Persian dictionary 1 as the translation resource. Dadashkarimi et al., showed that Google has better coverage than other English-Persian dictionaries. We evaluated 40 Persian POS tags in our experiments.

sections.heading: 3.2 Comparing Different Morphological Processing Methods
sections.text: In this section, we aim to evaluate the proposed SS4MCT method. To this end, we compare the proposed SS4MCT with a number of dictionary-based CLIR methods; the 5 gram truncation method (SPLIT) used in [11], rule-based query enhancement (RBQE) based on inflection / derivation rules from Farazzin machine translators and the STeP1 method are the morphological processing approaches for the retrieval system. On the other hand, we are conducting another set of experiments without applying a morphological processing method similar to the Persian state-of-the-art CLIR method.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion and Future Works
sections.text: SS4MCT extracts a number of morphological rules based on processing distances of a large number of pairs of words from a collection. Taking into account the juxtaposition of the characters in the rules and the evaluation of the method of informal text mining, these remain as future work.

metadata.abstractText: There have been multiple attempts to resolve various inflection matching problems in information retrieval. Stemming is a common approach to this end. Among many techniques for stemming, statistical stemming has been shown to be effective in a number of languages, particularly highly inflected languages. In this paper we propose a method for finding affixes in different positions of a word. Common statistical techniques heavily rely on string similarity in terms of prefix and suffix matching. Since infixes are common in irregular/informal inflections in morphologically complex texts, it is required to find infixes for stemming. In this paper we propose a method whose aim is to find statistical inflectional rules based on minimum edit distance table of word pairs and the likelihoods of the rules in a language. These rules are used to statistically stem words and can be used in different text mining tasks. Experimental results on CLEF 2008 and CLEF 2009 English-Persian CLIR tasks indicate that the proposed method significantly outperforms all the baselines in terms of MAP.
